This is the closest you can get to procedural auroras.

They are not truly procedural, but you will never see the same feature twice or with the same color.

I have now perfected the lightning behavior. I only have this pic just to give you an idea. It's really fast.

http://i.imgur.com/dG4lja0.png

Note that lightning may indeed strike in the same place, but not in the same way.

Astro: how do you get such hi-res sun flares? Did you increase the resolution of the DDS? Is that possible?

Astro: how do you get such hi-res sun flares? Did you increase the resolution of the DDS? Is that possible?

No, the resolution is the same. The trick is not in what information is there, but what information is perceivable. Color creates separation that alpha cannot. Thus I have lowered alpha by bringing the exposure down.

At a low resolution, pixelization lowers the number of light levels in a gradient. Lowering the difference in brightness value between each neighboring pixel makes the gradient appear smoother, without changing any rbg ratios that would bring that same detail to the image.

Besides, at this distance the smaller part of the lens flare is just more than half its actual size.
Is this compatible with .25?

Is this compatible with .25?

I haven't encountered any issues.

This is the closest you can get to procedural auroras.

http://i.imgur.com/4uPn2g3.jpg

They are not truly procedural, but you will never see the same feature twice or with the same color.

Are the auroras at a higher altitude than the clouds? I've been using one of your Interstellar test releases and the auroras seem way too low (i.e. in the atmosphere at like 40km). Then again they're also really flickery so that might be a configuration issue I wasn't aware of.

No, the resolution is the same. The trick is not in what information is there, but what information is perceivable. Color creates separation that alpha cannot. Thus I have lowered alpha by bringing the exposure down.

At a low resolution, pixelization lowers the number of light levels in a gradient. Lowering the difference in brightness value between each neighboring pixel makes the gradient appear smoother, without changing any rbg ratios that would bring that same detail to the image.

Besides, at this distance the smaller part of the lens flare is just more than half its actual size.

That's good to know, I've been struggling with banding in lens flares in an animation

The things you learn on this forum are always interesting

Are the auroras at a higher altitude than the clouds? I've been using one of your Interstellar test releases and the auroras seem way too low (i.e. in the atmosphere at like 40km). Then again they're also really flickery so that might be a configuration issue I wasn't aware of.

I have since calculated the reasonable aurora altitude for each body that has them.
